critique: This executive order pertains to the internal organization of the War Production Board during World War II. It adds members to the board. Given the context of wartime, the order likely centralizes authority to improve war production. There is no clear indication of ideological tilt, immigration policy, or impacts on civil liberties. The order seems to expand executive power to manage the war effort. It also appears to strengthen federal control over resources and production. There's no direct impact on social inclusion or economic regulation beyond wartime production needs.
